sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Azerbaijan is a country located at the crossroads of Eastern Europe and Western Asia, known for its rich oil reserves, diverse landscapes, and cultural blend of Turkic, Persian, and Russian influences.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Baku is the capital and largest city of Azerbaijan, famous for its modern skyline, historic Old City, and Caspian Sea coastline.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Azerbaijani manat (AZN).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Azerbaijani (Azeri), a Turkic language written in the Latin alphabet.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Popular dishes include plov (rice pilaf), dolma (stuffed vegetables), kebabs, piti (lamb stew), and qutab (stuffed flatbread).

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Azerbaijan features the Caspian Sea coastline, the Caucasus Mountains, semi-desert plains, and fertile valleys. It is also home to mud volcanoes and the Gobustan rock art site.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Azerbaijani culture blends Turkic traditions with Persian and Russian influences. Music, poetry, carpet weaving, and the national mugham style are central to its identity.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Flame Towers in Baku, Gobustan National Park, Sheki Khan’s Palace, mud volcanoes, and the Caspian Sea resorts.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Azerbaijan is known as the 'Land of Fire' due to its natural gas reserves and burning mountain, Yanar Dag, which has been aflame for centuries.

history.event: The region was part of Caucasian Albania, an ancient kingdom with its own language and culture.
Christianity spread into Caucasian Albania, though later Islam became dominant.
Arab Caliphate conquered the region, introducing Islam which became the majority religion.
Seljuk Turks settled in the region, shaping Azerbaijani language and culture.
Mongol invasions devastated cities and reshaped political structures.
Shah Ismail I founded the Safavid Empire, making Shia Islam the state religion in Azerbaijan.
Azerbaijan was divided into khanates, semi-independent principalities under Persian influence.
Northern Azerbaijan was annexed by the Russian Empire after the Treaty of Turkmenchay.
The Azerbaijan Democratic Republic was established, becoming the first secular democratic republic in the Muslim world.
The Soviet Union incorporated Azerbaijan as the Azerbaijan SSR.
Azerbaijan declared independence from the Soviet Union.
The First Nagorno-Karabakh War broke out between Azerbaijan and Armenia, leading to territorial disputes.
Ilham Aliyev became president, continuing his father Heydar Aliyev’s leadership legacy.
The Second Nagorno-Karabakh War resulted in Azerbaijan regaining significant territories.
